title: 112_s1484
content: The Act is titled the "Hyde and Related Amendments Codification Act" and it prohibits taxpayer-funded abortions while providing conscience protections in a new chapter added to Title 1 of the United States Code. The "Hyde and Related Amendments Codification Act" prohibits the use of federal funds for abortions and health benefits plans that cover abortion. It also includes provisions for exceptions in cases of rape, incest, or preserving the life of the mother. The "Hyde and Related Amendments Codification Act" prohibits federal funding for health benefits plans that cover abortion and restricts abortion services in federal facilities and by federal employees. Individuals, entities, or states can purchase separate abortion coverage as long as it is paid for with non-federal funds. The "Hyde and Related Amendments Codification Act" prohibits federal funding for health benefits plans that cover abortion. Individuals, entities, or states can purchase separate abortion coverage using non-federal funds without restrictions on contracting with providers for such coverage. The "Hyde and Related Amendments Codification Act" prohibits federal funding for health benefits plans that cover abortion. Separate abortion coverage can be purchased using non-federal funds without restrictions on contracting with providers. This chapter does not affect other federal laws limiting funds for abortion or health benefits coverage including abortion. It also clarifies that complications arising from abortion treatment are not covered under this chapter. Abortion related to rape, incest, or preserving the life of the mother is subject to specific limitations. The "Hyde and Related Amendments Codification Act" prohibits federal funding for health plans covering abortion, but exceptions are made for cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is in danger. The Act also applies to funds in the District of Columbia approved by Congress. Sec. 310 prohibits government discrimination against health care entities that do not provide, pay for, or refer for abortions. The term 'health care entity' includes various healthcare providers and organizations. The courts of the United States are responsible for enforcing remedies. The courts of the United States have jurisdiction to prevent and redress violations of Sec. 310 by issuing legal or equitable relief, including injunctions and orders preventing the disbursement of Federal financial assistance until the prohibited conduct has ceased. An action under this subsection may be initiated by any health care entity with standing to complain of a violation. An action under this subsection may be initiated by any health care entity with standing to complain of a violation, or by the Attorney General of the United States. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will designate the Director of the Office for Civil Rights to receive and investigate complaints related to violations of this section. The Secretary of Health and Human Services designates the Director of the Office for Civil Rights to investigate complaints related to violations of this section. Additionally, any health care entity or the Attorney General of the United States can initiate an action under this subsection. The table of chapters for title 1, United States Code, is amended to include a new item regarding the referral of complaints to the appropriate office of another agency receiving Federal financial assistance. Prohibiting taxpayer funded abortions and providing conscience protections.
